section.title: Bindings
section.t: Bindings define how a FOSP message is transported via an existing protocol. Currently a binding for the WebSocket protocol is defined and a binding for HTTP is being worked on.

section.title: WebSocket binding
section.t: The WebSocket binding provides a way of sending FOSP messages of WebSocket messages. It was chosen because it is the only bidirectional protocol currently supported in browsers.

section.title: Connection Initiation
section.t: To send messages to a server over WebSockets, a connection has to be established first. How the server address, port and URL path are determined for a given domain is discussed in . In the WebSocket handshake, the Sec-WebSocket-Protocol MUST be set to "fosp".

section.title: Format
section.t: The FOSP messages is formatted similar to a HTTP request/response.

WARNING: To simplify the definition for the moment, only ASCII characters are used. This WILL change as the protocol itself mandates the use of Unicode and the UTF-8 encoding and international user and resource names MUST be supported Also the header definition will be subject to change after determining acceptable characters. For the resource identifier, we will probably refer to the IRI definition in the future.

section.title: Serialization
section.t: Messages are serialized into a blob of bytes and sent inside a single WebSocket message. Most of the message is text in UTF-8 encoding, only the body is either a valid JSON object, UTF-8 encoded, or raw bytes. The second case occurs when an attachment is up- or downloaded. The beginning and end, e.g. the length of a message must be determined from lenght of the WebSocket message.

When a message contains binary data that is not UTF-8 encoded text, e.g. a WRITE request, a binary WebSocket message MUST be used. Otherwise, when the whole message is valid UTF-8 encoded text, a text WebSocket message CAN be used.

section.title: HTTP binding
section.t: The HTTP binding is developed because it might be simpler for clients to process large up- or downloads via HTTP. However, it does not support all of FOSPs functionality because notifications can not be sent over HTTP (at least over HTTP/1.1).

section.title: Mapping
section.t: Each FOSP request is transported as an HTTP request. The request identifier is used as the HTTP method. The HTTP request-URI MUST be the absolute URI of the FOSP object. The HTTP headers are the FOSP headers. The HTTP body is the FOSP body.

section.title: Session management
section.t: To support authenticated requests, a FOSP server that supports the HTTP binding MUST return a cookie in a success response to a BIND request. With this cookie, the client is able to make authenticated requests.
